news.title: From New York To Romania, Restoration Ecology Is Helping Nature (And Humanity) Heal
news.summary: Mihnea Tanasescu, Vrije Universiteit Brussel New York City’s Bronx River used to be an open sewer, more useful for carrying industrial waste than for hosting fish.

news.title: From New York to Romania, restoration ecology is helping nature heal (and maybe humanity, too)
news.summary: 29 minutes ago Mihnea Tanasescu, The Conversation Share Tweet Email Reddit Print Share Tweet Email Reddit Print New York City’s Bronx river used to be an open sewer, more useful for carrying industrial waste than for hosting fish.

facebook.summary:
"If restoration is feasible, then what’s to stop mining companies from blowing mountains up and then just “repairing” them?"

Mihnea Tanasescu, Research Fellow, Environmental Political Theory, Vrije Universiteit Brussel

facebook.title: From New York to Romania, restoration ecology is helping nature heal (and maybe humanity, too)
facebook.summary: 'New York City’s Bronx River used to be an open sewer, more useful for carrying industrial waste than for hosting fish. Today, thanks to the efforts of environmental groups and the communities that live along this 37-kilometre stretch of water, the river i

facebook.title: From New York to Romania, restoration ecology is helping nature heal (and maybe humanity, too)
facebook.summary: In the 1930s, Aldo Leopold led the world’s first restoration project, the University of Wisconsin Arboretum, which established the basis of modern restoration ecology: returning degraded environments to their pre-disturbance states.

facebook.title: From New York to Romania, restoration ecology is helping nature heal (and maybe humanity, too)
facebook.summary:
Restoration ecology, rewilding and the debate around its success or futility. For the pragmatists:
 "But, they say, if we can make terrible situations better for people and nature alike, why not try?"
